topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Sander Schulhoff’s credentials (early prompt engineering guide, HackAPrompt, The Prompt Report) and previews the episode’s structure: basic prompting techniques, advanced techniques, and prompt injection/red teaming.

topics.title: Is prompt engineering still worth learning?
topics.summary: They debate whether prompting is becoming obsolete; Sander argues it remains important and frames it as “artificial social intelligence,” i.e., learning how to communicate effectively with AIs.

topics.title: Real-world impact: medical coding prompt improvements
topics.summary: Sander shares a case study where adding curated examples and reasoning to a prompt dramatically improved GPT-4’s medical coding accuracy (roughly +70%), illustrating how prompt quality can swing outcomes.

topics.title: Two modes: conversational vs product prompting
topics.summary: Sander distinguishes everyday iterative chatbot prompting from product-focused prompting where a single prompt (or small set) must reliably handle large-scale production traffic; Lenny reframes this as “product-focused prompt engineering.”

topics.title: Basic technique: few-shot prompting and formatting
topics.summary: Sander recommends few-shot prompting as a high-impact baseline: provide examples of desired inputs/outputs (or just outputs) using common, training-data-familiar formats (Q/A, XML, etc.) to improve reliability.

topics.title: What no longer works: role prompting and threats
topics.summary: They discuss techniques that are overhyped today: role prompting doesn’t reliably improve accuracy tasks on modern models (though it can help style/expressive tasks), and “I’ll tip you / someone will die” reward-threat prompts likely don’t help.

topics.title: Basic technique: decomposition into subproblems
topics.summary: Sander explains decomposition: ask the model to list subproblems needed to solve a complex request, then solve them stepwise—useful both conversationally and in product/agent architectures (e.g., car dealership return-policy workflow).

topics.title: Basic technique: self-criticism and revision loops
topics.summary: They cover self-criticism: have the model produce an answer, critique it, then implement improvements—often a “free” quality boost, typically done 1–3 iterations before diminishing returns.

topics.title: Basic technique: add rich task information
topics.summary: Sander emphasizes adding relevant background (“additional information”) to improve outputs; he shares an entrapment-detection research example where removing contextual text caused performance to drop sharply, plus notes on cost/latency and caching when placing info at the top.

topics.title: Prompt anatomy vs prompting techniques
topics.summary: Sander distinguishes prompt components (role, examples, directive, output format, additional info) from “prompting techniques” intended to induce performance gains, referencing how The Prompt Report categorizes these ideas and their history.

topics.title: Advanced technique: ensembling and reasoning experts
topics.summary: They discuss ensembling: run multiple prompts (or models) on the same problem and aggregate (e.g., majority vote). Sander highlights “mixture of reasoning experts,” where different prompted ‘experts’ or tool-enabled variants compete to improve final accuracy.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Ad read for Vanta, describing automated compliance and security programs (SOC 2, ISO 27001) and offering a listener discount.

topics.title: Chain-of-thought prompting in the reasoning era
topics.summary: They revisit chain-of-thought/thought-generation prompting: it’s less necessary with reasoning models, but Sander notes non-reasoning models can be inconsistent (occasionally skipping reasoning), so explicit “show your reasoning” instructions can still stabilize performance.
